Stream HISTORY Try By: HISTORY.com Editors Cold War The Space Race HISTORY.com Editors HUM Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images Published: February 22, 2010 Last Updated: January 15, 2026 Table of contents 1 Causes of the Space Race 2 NASA Is Created 3 Space Race Heats Up: Men (And Chimps) Orbit Earth 4 Achievements of Apollo 5 Who Won the Space Race? Table of contents After World War II drew to a close in the mid-20th century, a new conflict began. Known as the Cold War, this battle

of contents After World War II drew to a close in the mid-20th century, a new conflict began. Known as the Cold War, this battle pitted the world’s two great powers—the democratic, capitalist United States and the communist Soviet Union—against each other. Beginning in the late 1950s, space became another dramatic arena for this competition, as each side sought to prove the superiority of its technology, its military firepower and–by extension–its political and economic system. Causes of the Space Race By the mid-1950s, the U.S.-Soviet Cold War had worked its way into the fabric of everyday life in both countries, fueled by the arms race and the growing threat of nuclear weapons, wide-ranging espionage and counterespionage between the two countries, war in Korea and a clash of words and ideas carried out in the media. These tensions would continue throughout the space race, exacerbated by such events as the construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961, the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962 and the outbreak of war in Southeast Asia.
